Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Role of Suppressor of Sessile Spikelet1 (sos1) in Meristem Maintenance and Determinacy
Award.AbstractNarration:
All grasses produce spikelets, short branches bearing the florets, which produce the kernels or grain, and therefore much of the calories that feed the world. Maize, and closely related grasses, produce spikelets in pairs, doubling the number of kernels produced in contrast to other, more distantly related cereals, such as rice, wheat and barley, which produce spikelets singly. Understanding the molecular and developmental basis for paired spikelet formation is of great practical significance as this information could be used to double yield in cereals that produce single spikelets. Collaborative comparative genomic studies also provide an unprecedented opportunity to understand the molecular basis for the evolution of this derived trait.

The identification of the suppressor of sessile spikelet (sos) loci in maize provides a breakthrough into the understanding of the formation of the paired spikelet. Molecular, cellular and developmental approaches will be used to dissect the function of Sos1. Additional molecular and developmental studies of Sos2 and Sos3 will enable the identification of additional genes regulating paired spikelet formation. The paired spikelet is produced by a meristem called the spikelet pair meristem. Meristems continually produce organs through balancing the functions of maintenance and determinacy. The Sos loci will enable the dissection of the interaction between these two fundamental developmental processes, as well as providing insight into the evolution of grass inflorescence architecture.

This research involves collaboration between a maize developmental geneticist and an expert in the evolution of grasses, and hence is interdisciplinary in nature. One graduate student and at least six undergraduate students will be trained in the McSteen laboratory. A summer seminar series will be developed to provide training for undergraduates in understanding the broader implications of evolutionary studies in science, education, and society. The PI will also speak to the public on the domestication of corn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All grasses produce spikelets, short branches bearing the florets, which produce the kernels or grain, and therefore much of the calories that feed the world. Maize, and closely related grasses, produce spikelets in pairs, doubling the number of kernels produced in contrast to other, more distantly related cereals, such as rice and wheat, which produce spikelets singly. Understanding the molecular and developmental basis for paired spikelet formation is of great practical significance as this information could be used to double yield in cereals that produce single spikelets. The identification of the suppressor of sessile spikelet (sos) loci in maize provide a breakthrough into the understanding of the formation of the paired spikelet as the mutants produce single instead of paired spikelets. Molecular, cellular and developmental approaches were used to dissect the function of three sos loci in maize. 

In plants, meristems continually produce organs through balancing the functions of maintenance (the ability of the meristem to continually produce organs) and determinacy (the production of a set number of organs by the meristem, which is closely associated with its identity). The paired spikelet is produced by a meristem called the spikelet pair meristem. Previous work indicated that regulation of meristem determinacy played an important role in the development of the paired spikelet in maize. This research identified two additional mechanisms as being important.

Intellectual Merit

Aim 1. Determine the developmental processes underlying the defects in the Sos1 mutant: We obtained very strong genetic and molecular evidence for the function of sos1 in meristem maintenance.

Aim 2. Determine the genetic and molecular basis for the Sos1 phenotype: We determined that the Sos1 mutant is caused by a defect in the CLAVATA meristem maintenance pathway providing an entry point into a mechanistic understanding of the control of this trait.

Aim 3. Compare the genomic context, sequence, expression and function of sos1 in other grasses to provide insight into the evolution of this derived trait: This was a collaborative grant with Toby Kellogg’s lab at the Danforth Plant Science Center, who determined the function of sos1 in Setaria and the evolution of the sos1 gene family in the grasses. Furthermore, we discovered that there are multiple independent origins of the paired spikelet trait in the grasses, which mapped the origin of the trait back much earlier than anticipated.

Aim 4. We proposed to engage undergraduate students in analyzing additional Sos mutants to identity additional loci involved. We have made significant progress on the mapping, sequencing and characterization of two additional Sos mutants. We determined that sos2 functions in the transition between meristem types at every stage of development in maize and have identified strong candidate genes for the mutation by fine mapping and resequencing. We have determined that sos3 function is more similar to sos1.

Broader Impacts

Training: This research involved collaboration between a maize developmental geneticist and an expert in the evolution of grasses, and hence was interdisciplinary in nature. Two postdoctoral fellows (both female), one Masters and one PhD student (both female), three rotating graduate students (two female), fifteen undergraduate students including eight Freshman Research in Plant Sciences (FRIPS) undergraduate students (five female) and five summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) undergraduate students (including three female, three from Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUI) and two minorities) were trained on the grant.

Integration of research with undergraduate education: Besides enabling students to be involved in undergraduate research in the McSteen lab this grant broadened the impact on undergraduate education through involvement in two programs at MU. 1) FRIPS - The FRIPS program recruits freshman undergraduate students at MU to work in plant science labs for the academic year. This grant funded seven FRIPS students, three of which worked in the McSteen lab until their graduation. 2) EvoRES – Evolution in Research, Education and Society, a science and society seminar series was offered in Summer 2015, 2015 and 2016 to expose undergraduate students to the implications of science in society through discussion of the educational, societal and legal implications of teaching evolution. Around 15 undergraduate students enrolled every summer in the seminar series, half were from PUI and one quarter were members of underrepresented groups.

Public outreach: Participants on this grant participated in science education with the public in the MU Saturday Morning Science seminar series, MU South Farm Showcase, Missouri Future Farmers of America, Donald Danforth Plant Science Center conversations series and Benton Elementary after school science club.
